h3.a: Ending the year in our Continuous Learning plan

span.span: At our board meeting on April 13, the board of education passed a motion to end the delivery of new material to students on May 1. Students will have until May 15 to complete any missing work. All work will be due by May 15 and no work will be accepted as late or otherwise after May 15. Even though students are not in our buildings, school is happening and we are seeing that some students are doing a great job of keeping on task and getting the work done, while others are having difficulty in keeping work done. If we were in class in normal circumstances, we would have those students in our 8th period completing the work and getting extra help. We don't have that option right now, so in an effort to give our students and families a light at the end of the tunnel and the opportunity to get the work completed, we asked the board to end the delivery of new information on May 1. This will allow our students and families some extra time to work through what at times may seem to be overwhelming.

To do this right, we need to make sure we are doing everything we can to help your students be successful. We need you to help keep the students following the schedule as best you can, and help them understand that they need to continue to work to stay on track and work hard to complete their current assignments on time. However, if you are not able to get it all done by May 1, you will have until May 15 to make sure it is done. That doesn't mean it should be put off until the last two weeks; if students do that they may be in danger of not being able to earn the credit for the semester. If you or your students are having difficulty with any assignment please reach out to your student's teachers. They are able and willing to help, through use of zoom or Google meets, email, text or phone calls if necessary. The teachers are doing a good job of keeping us informed of the work being done, and we will continue to encourage them to keep the lines of communication open and working.

Also discussed was graduation for this year. After meeting with the seniors and taking a poll, it was determined that we would move the ceremony to July 3. In part this was due to the health directives and the size of the crowds being allowed at one time. We are hopeful that by moving the date to July 3 we can have a closer to normal ceremony than would be allowed on the original date of May 16. As we get closer to the date, it is hopeful that we will have better information on how the ceremony can be conducted. We will follow the guidelines we are given regarding the number of people and the amount of social distancing needed, which may change how the ceremony looks. However, we will do what we have in our power to make sure our seniors are able to have a graduation ceremony this year.

This has been a difficult time for all of us and we appreciate what you have been doing to help. Together we are doing all we can to help our students succeed now and in the future. We are better together.

a.aria-label: Read more about Ending the year in our Continuous Learning plan

h3.a: Continuous Learning K-3 Packet Pick up and Drop Off Schedule

p.span: The following schedule is for the Pick up and Drop Off of Packets for our K-3 Students.

This schedule will begin on Thursday April 9, 2020 and will end at the end of the school year. We will conduct the pick up and drop off every Thursday during this time. Dates are as follows 4/9/2020, 4/16/2020, 4/23/2020, 4/30/2020, 5/7/2020, 5/14/2020.

span.strong: These dates are subject to change so please refer back to this page for updates to the schedule.

div.p: Please remember that times are approximate, it would be best to arrive at your site a little early if possible.

h3.a: Continuous Learning at Arthur County Schools

span.b: Arthur County Schools will remain closed until May 1st or further notice. Please continue to visit our website to stay up-to-date on the latest information.

We are experiencing a shift in how schools, communities, and our society function. And the fact is, we do not know what’s going to happen or how it’s going to happen. We are uncertain how this will unfold. What we do know is that we are all in this together, and we are better together. Education is not contained to four walls. It is a service that educators are deeply committed to. To this extent, teachers in Arthur County Schools are relocating the learning from the traditional classroom inside the building to distance learning classrooms online or through learning packets.

The move to an alternate learning environment will mean a shift in mindset and skills, as well as a shift in delivery of instruction. We will continue to provide the best education for your students. The entire staff and administration at Arthur County Schools have worked diligently to develop a Continuity of Learning Plan that best meets the needs of all our students and allow for credits to be awarded for the 2nd semester.
A copy of the plan is included in our recent mailing and is available by following this link. (ACS Continuous Learning Plan)

Please review the plan thoroughly and take special notice that the 4th nine weeks will no longer consist of “enrichment activities” only, but is instead shifting to a Pass/Fail grading system. A schedule is also outlined for Grades 4-12.

Continue to check our website for updates regarding our building closures and do not hesitate to contact us with any questions. Together we are better, and we appreciate all you are doing to help us continue in education! If you have any questions please do not hesitate to contact us at the High School phone number - (308) 764-2253.

a.aria-label: Read more about Continuous Learning at Arthur County Schools
